qudipy.system package

Submodules

qudipy.system.dot_array module

Primary data type for handeling field information and effective parameter calculations for electrostatically defined quantum dots.

@author: Zach, Bohdan

class qudipy.system.dot_array.DotArray(ctrl_names: list[str], ctrl_vals: list[list[int]] = 'nextnano', file_prefix: str = 'dots', eff_interp_dims: list[int] = 'nextnano', material: str = 'Si/SiO2', exchange_method: str = 'HM', def_masking: str = 'gaussian', calc: list[str] = ['spin'], save: bool = True, n_dots: int = 2)

Bases: Exchange, Gfactor

This class is designed to process the potential landscape data set for a given device dot geometry to exctract various meta data or effective parameters.

Example: find the the number of dots for the potential lanscape dataset and then calculate the g-factor deviation for each dot and exchange for all pars of adjacent dots.

Atributes

analytic(pot_func, x_range=None, y_range=None, coords=None)

A wrapper function to create DotArray objects using analytic potentials.

Required Parameters

pot_func: func

Potential function that expects to use a mesh grid created from coordiante arrays or from a GridParameters object.

Optional Parameters2

x_range: array

Array of x-coordinate values.

y_range: array

Array of y-coordinate values.

coords: dict{key:array}

Dictionary containing arrays for x/y-coordinates.

returns:

self – DotArray object with added potential interpolator.

rtype:

DotArray object

numeric(precalculated_dir, data_dir, preprocessed_dir)

Initializes the Dots class object.

Required Parameters

run_name: str

Name to append to output filename for HPC progress text file.

precalculated_dir: str

Data directory where pre-calculated data is stored/saved.

data_dir: string

Directory where nextnano raw data is save

preprocessed_dir: str

Directory where 2D slices are loaded from or saved too.

n_dots: int

Expected number of dots in the system

ctrl_names: list

list of all control names from nextnano input script.

Optional Parameters2

ctrl_vals: list of 1d arrays

List of control values for all control names to use to construct the effective parameter interpolators. Default is ‘nextnano’: raw nextnano data only is used as parameter grid for interpolator

eff_interp_dims: List[int], or int, or ‘nextnano’

Number of points per control parameter sweep to use to evaluate effective parameter interpolators (evenly spaced within min-max values of nextnano data). If a single integer is specified, then it determines the # of points / sweep for each control. Default is ‘nextnano’: the # of points in raw nextnano data. Note: if ctrl_vals is specified, it has priority over this parameter

file_prefix: str

Prefix added to saved/loaded files

material: str

Material system under consideration. Defaults to ‘Si/SiO2’

def_masking: str

Choice of masking method: ‘harsh’ (fast), or ‘gauss’/’gaussian’ (smooth). Order-specific masks are to be implemented. Default is ‘gaussian’.

calc: list[str]

Calculate effective parameters or check and load pre-existing effective parameter interpolation objects. Each element of the list is a string specifiy types of effective parameters to be calculated. Examples are: ‘spin’, ‘hubbard’, etc. Default is ‘spin’.

save: bool

Save 2D potential slices to Pre-processed directory unless it had been calculated previously. Default is True

rtype:

None.

plot(ctrl_vecs: list[numpy.ndarray], param: str = 'g-factor', exact: bool = False, plot_units: list[str] = ['J'], axis_units: list[str] = ['V', 'm'], yscale: str = 'linear', **mpl_params)
Method for fast and convenient plotting of effective parameters

print(‘Effective parameter interpolator saved as

‘, self.eff_file)

ctrl_vecslist of lists/numpy arrays

List of voltage configurations. Only one parameter should change between them

paramstr, optional

g-factors or exchanges to plot, by default ‘g-factor’

exactbool, optional

Calculate directly(True) or use effective interpolation objects (False), by default False

plot_unitslist[str], optional

List of two strings [‘unit’, ‘prefix’] specifying units for plotting (if figure is to be plotted), by default SI units are assumed.

axis_unitslist[str], optional

List of two strings [‘unit’, ‘prefix’] specifying units for figure axis (if figure is to be plotted), by default SI units are assumed.

yscalestr, optional

Linear or logarithmic vertical scale, by default ‘linear’

plot_sweep(ctrl_vec: list[list[list[float]]], param='g-factor', init_config: ndarray = 'min', ex_units='J', yscale='linear', n_sweep_pts=40)

Method for fast and convenient plotting of effective parameter control variable sweeps.

Required Parameters

ctrl_veclist of lists[float]

List of voltage ranges for control variables i.e.

Example:

ctrl_vec = [[V1_start, V1_end], [W1_start, W1_end], …]

Optional Parameters

paramstr, optional

g-factors or exchanges to plot, by default ‘g-factor’

init_config1D array

Initial configuration of control parameters (voltages). By default, minimum values of each control are taken (‘min’ keyword)

ex_unitsstr, optional

String specifying units of exchange (if plotted), by default ‘J’ (joules)

yscalestr, optional

Linear or logarithmic vertical scale, by default ‘linear’

n_sweep_ptsint

Number of points to sweep for each control parameter.

rtype:

None.

split(group='single', masking: str = 'default') → list

Method that defines new Dots objects where potentials of quantum dots are separated either individually or as pairs.

Each of the new Dots object inherits the potential and electric field data from the parent object, but the interpolating function changes: when called, the potential landscape appears to have only one dot (or one pair)

Optional Parameters

group: string

Whether to get a list of individual dots (‘single’/’singles’), or a list of adjacent dot pairs (‘pair’/’pairs’)

masking: str
Choice of masking method. By default, use the default masking method
of the DotArray class object. Other options include ‘harsh’ (fast),

‘gaussian’ (optimal, order-specific ones are to be implemented).

returns:

split_dots – list of Dots objects corresponding to individual dots or their pairs

rtype:

list

qudipy.system.state module

State class: handles spin, orbital, valley and Hubbard state information

class qudipy.system.state.State(spin: list[float], N_0: int = None, time: float = 0, T_1: float = inf, T_2: float = inf, T=0)

Bases: object

The class describes the spin state of the qubit system. Will be extended to orbital, Hubbard, valley, etc. states in the future.

Attributes comprise the system density matrix and spin environment parameters (temperature, T1, T2).

Methods construct Hamiltonian, and time-evolve the Lindblad equation with pulses.

rho

Density matrix. Initialized with the value before pulse

Type:

2D complex array

N_0
Maximal possible number of electrons in the system (could be bigger

than the dimensions of rho; useful in case we load new electrons.

Type:

int

time

Point in time [s] at which the system is defined.

Type:

float

T_1

Spin relaxation time [s].

Type:

float

T_2

Spin dephasing time [s].

Type:

float

T

Temperature [K].

Type:

float

cdict

Collection of costant matrices used to speed up the simulation. Have all the dimensinons from 2 x 2 up to 2**N_0 x 2**N_0.

Type:

dictionary of 2D complex arrays

evolve(pulse, rho_reference=None, eval_fidelity=False, eval_purity=False,
track_qubits=None, eval_Bloch_vectors=False,

track_points_per_pulse=100):

Performs system evolution under given pulse(s).
Outputs a dictionary of the specified tracking parameters

#TODO make it EvolutionData object

evolve(pulses: list[qudipy.circuit.control_pulse.ControlPulse], rho_reference: ndarray = None, eval_fidelity: bool = False, eval_purity: bool = False, track_qubits: list[int] = None, eval_Bloch_vectors: bool = False, track_points_per_pulse: int = 1000) → dict

Function that performs spin system evolution under the external pulse, i.e. updates the system density matrix. Required Parameters ———- pulses : ControlPulse object, or tuple/list of such objects

Contains pulse parameters at different points of time. The tuple/ list of pulses could be specified as an irregular array like [pulse1, pulse2, [pulse3, (pulse4, pulse5)], pulse6], which is convenient for dealing with compound pulses.

Optional Parameters

rho_reference: 2D complex array, optional

The density matrix (initial, anticipated final, etc.) to compare with the density matrix during the simulation. If specified, the fidelity of system density matrix with respect to it can be calculated. The default is None.

eval_fidelitybool, optional

Indicates whether to track the fidelity of the density matrix with respect to the specified rho_reference (if it is specified). The default is False.

eval_puritybool, optional

Indicates whether to track the purity of the density matrix. The default is False.

track_qubitsint / iterable of ints, optional

Index (indices) of qubit(s) to track during the pulse(s) (i. e. evaluate 1-qubit density submatrices for them). The default is None.

eval_Bloch_vectors: bool, optional

Indicates whether to calculate Bloch vectors for the tracked qubits along with their density submatrices. The default is False.

track_points_per_pulse: int, optional

Number of points of time during the simulation to save the tracked parameters specified above and then output them. The default is 1000.

returns:

ret_dict – Includes some of the following pairs key-value (the length of each array is given by track_points_per_pulse variable): - “time”: 1D float array

Points of time that correspond to the values contained in the other arrays defined below.

  • “purity”: 1D float array

    Purity of the system density matrix (if eval_purity is True).

  • “fidelity”: 1D float array

    Fidelity of the system density matrix with respect to rho_reference (if it is defined, and if eval_fidelity is True).

  • “submatrix_{i}”: 1D array of complex 2D arrays

    Density submatrix of the i-th electron, if i is in track_qubits iterable.

  • “sigma_x_{i}” : 1D float array “sigma_y_{i}” : 1D float array “sigma_z_{i}” : 1D float array

    Bloch vector components of the i-th electron, if i is in track_qubits iterable, and eval_Bloch_vectors is True.

rtype:

dictionary of numpy arrays

Module contents

Code for dot array module containing various classes and functions.
